(As I confess it is my Natures plague
To spy into Abuses, and of my jealousy
Shapes faults that are not) that your wisdom
From one, that so imperfectly conceits,
Would take no notice, nor build yourself a trouble
Out of his scattering, and unsure observance:
It were not for your quiet, nor your good,
Nor for my Manhood, Honesty, and Wisdom,
To let you know my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Good name in Man, & woman (dear my Lord)
Is the immediate Jewel of their Souls;
Who steals my purse, steals trash:
It is something, nothing;
It was mine, it is his, and has been slave to thousands:
But he that filches from me my good Name,
Robs me of that, which not enriches him,
And makes me poor indeed.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I will know thy Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: You cannot, if my heart were in your hand,
Nor shall not, whilst it is in my custody.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: O, beware my Lord, of jealousy,
It is the green-eyed Monster, which doth mock
The meat it feeds on. That Cuckold lives in bliss,
Who certain of his Fate, loves not his wronger:
But o, what damned minutes tells he over,
Who dotes, yet doubts: Suspects, yet soundly loves?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O misery.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Poor, and Content, is rich, and rich enough,
But Riches fineless, is as poor as Winter,
To him that ever fears he shall be poor:
Good Heaven, the Souls of all my Tribe defend
From Jealousy.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Why? why is this?
Thinkest thou, I would make a Life of Jealousy;
To follow still the changes of the Moon
With fresh suspicions? No: to be once in doubt,
Is to be resolved: Exchange me for a Goat,
When I shall turn the business of my Soul
To such exufflicate, and blowed Surmises,
Matching thy inference. It is not to make me Jealous,
To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company,
Is free of Speech, Sings, Plays, and Dances:
Where Virtue is, these are more virtuous.
Nor from mine own weak merits, will I draw
The smallest fear, or doubt of her revolt,
For she had eyes, and chose me. No Iago,
I will see before I doubt; when I doubt, prove;
And on the proof, there is no more but this,
Away at once with Love, or Jealousy.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I am glad of this: For now I shall have reason
To show the Love and Duty that I bear you
With franker spirit. Therefore (as I am bound)
Receive it from me. I speak not yet of proof:
Look to your wife, observe her well with Cassio,
Wear your eyes, thus: not Jealous, nor Secure:
I would not have your free, and Noble Nature,
Out of self-Bounty, be abused: Look to it:
I know our Country disposition well:
In Venice, they do let Heaven see the pranks
They dare not show their Husbands.
Their best Conscience,
Is not to leave it undone, but kept unknown.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Dost thou say so?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: She did deceive her Father, marrying you,
And when she seemed to shake, and fear your looks,
She loved them most.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: And so she did.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Why go too then:
She that so young could give out such a Seeming
To seal her Fathers eyes up, close as Oak,
He thought it was Witchcraft.
But I am much to blame:
I humbly do beseech you of your pardon
For too much loving you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I am bound to thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I see this hath a little dashed your Spirits:

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Not a jot, not a jot.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Trust me, I fear it has:
I hope you will consider what is spoke
Comes from your Love.
But I do see you are moved:
I am to pray you, not to strain my speech
To grosser issues, nor to larger reach,
Then to Suspicion.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Should you do so (my Lord)
My speech should fall into such vild success,
Which my Thoughts aimed not.
Cassio's my worthy Friend:
My Lord, I see you are moved.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: No, not much moved:
I do not think but Desdemona's honest.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Long live she so;
And long live you to think so.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: And yet how Nature erring from itself.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Aye, there is the point:
As (to be bold with you)
Not to affect many proposed Matches
Of her own Clime, Complexion, and Degree,
Whereto we see in all things, Nature tends:
Foh, one may smell in such, a will most rank,
Foul disproportions, Thoughts unnatural.
But (pardon me) I do not in position
Distinctly speak of her, though I may fear
Her will, recoiling to her better judgment,
May fall to match you with her Country forms,
And happily repent.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Farewell, farewell:
If more thou dost perceive, let me know more:
Set on thy wife to observe.
Leave me Iago.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: My Lord, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Othel.
sp.l: Why did I marry?
This honest Creature (doubtless)
Sees, and knows more, much more than he unfolds.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: My Lord, I would I might entreat your Honour
To scan this thing no farther: Leave it to time,
Although it is fit that Cassio have his Place;
For sure he fills it up with great Ability;
Yet if you please, to him off awhile:
You shall by that perceive him, and his means:
Note if your Lady strain his Encertainment
With any strong, or vehement importunity,
Much will be seen in that: In the mean time,
Let me be thought too busy in my fears,
(As worthy cause I have to fear I am)
And hold her free, I do beseech your Honour.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Fear not my government.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I once more take my leave.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: This Fellow is of exceeding honesty,
And knows all Quantities with a learned Spirit
Of human dealings. If I do prove her Haggard,
Though that her Jesses were my dear heart-strings,
I would whistle her off, and let her down the wind
To prey at Fortune. Happily, for I am black,
And have not those soft parts of Conversation
That Chamberers have: Or for I am declined
Into the vale of years (yet that is not much)
She is gone. I am abused, and my relief
Must be to loath her. O Curse of Marriage!
That we can call these delicate Creatures ours,
And not their Appetites? I had rather be a Toad,
And live upon the vapour of a Dungeon,
Than keep a corner in the thing I love
For others uses. Yet it is the plague to Great-ones,
Prerogatived are they less than the Base,
It is destiny unshunnable, like death:
Even then, this forked plague is Fated to us,
When we do quicken. Look where she comes:
If she be false, Heaven mocked itself:
I will not believe it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: How now, my dear Othello?
Your dinner, and the generous Islanders
By you invited, do attend your presence.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I am to blame.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why do you speak so faintly?
Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I have a pain upon my Forehead, here.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why that is with watching, it will away again.
Let me but bind it hard, within this hour
It will be well.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Your Napkin is too little:
Let it alone: Come, I will go in with you.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I am very sorry that you are not well.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: I am glad I have found this Napkin:
This was her first remembrance from the Moor,
My wayward Husband hath a hundred times
Wooed me to steal it. But she so loves the Token,
(For he conjured her, she should ever keep it)
That she reserves it evermore about her,
To kiss, and talk too. I will have the work taken out,
And give it Iago: what he will do with it
Heaven knows, not I:
Aye nothing, but to please his Fantasy.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: How now? What do you here alone?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Do not you chide: I have a thing for you.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: You have a thing for me?
It is a common thing---

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: To have a foolish wife.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: O, is that all? What will you give me now
For that same Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: What Handkerchief?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: What Handkerchief?
Why that the Moor first gave to Desdemona,
That which so often you did bid me steal.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Hast stolen it from her?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: No: but she let it drop by negligence,
And to the advantage, I being here, took it up:
Look, here it is.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: A good wench, give it me.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: What will you do with it, that you have been
so earnest to have me filch it?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Why, what is that to you?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: If it be not for some purpose of import,
Give it me again. Poor Lady, she will run mad
When she shall lack it.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Be not acknowne of it:
I have use for it. Go, leave me. Exit Aemil.
I will in Cassio's Lodging loose this Napkin,
And let him find it. Trifles light as air,
Are to the jealous, confirmations strong,
As proofs of holy Writ. This may do something.
The Moor already changes with my poison:
Dangerous conceits, are in their Natures poisons,
Which at the first are scarce found to distaste:
But with a little act upon the blood,
Burn like the Mines of Sulphur. I did say so.
Look where he comes: Not Poppy, nor Mandragora,
Nor all the drowsy Syrups of the world
Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep
Which thou owedest yesterday.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Ha, ha, false to me?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Why how now General? No more of that.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Avaunt, be gone: Thou hast set me on the Rack:
I swear it is better to be much abused,
Than but to know it a little.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: How now, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What sense had I, in her stolen hours of Lust?
I saw it not, thought it not: it harmed not me:
I slept the next night well, fed well, was free, and merry.
I found not Cassio's kisses on her Lips:
He that is robbed, not wanting what is stolen,
Let him not know it, and he is not robbed at all.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I am sorry to hear this?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I had been happy, if the general Camp,
Pioneers and all, had tasted her sweet Body,
So I had nothing known. O now, for ever
Farewell the Tranquil mind; farewell Content;
Farewell the plumed Troops, and the big Wars,
That makes Ambition, Virtue! O farewell;
Farewell the neighing Steed, and the shrill Trump,
The Spirit-stirring Drum, the Ear-piercing Fife,
The Royal Banner, and all Quality,
Pride, Pomp, and Circumstance of glorious War:
And O you mortal Engines, whose rude throats
The immortal Ioues dread Clamours, counterfeit,
Farewell: Othello's Occupation's gone.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Is it possible my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Villain, be sure thou prove my Love a Whore;
Be sure of it: Give me the Ocular proof,
Or by the worth of mine eternal Soul,
Thou hadst been better have been born a Dog
Than answer my waked wrath.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Is it come to this?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Make me to see it: or (at the least) so prove it,
That the probation bear no Hinge, nor Loop,
To hang a doubt on: Or woe upon thy life.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: My Noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: If thou dost slander her, and torture me,
Never pray more: Abandon all remorse
On Horrors head, Horrors accumulate:
Do deeds to make Heaven weep, all Earth amazed;
For nothing canst thou to damnation add,
Greater than that.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: O Grace! O Heaven forgive me!
Are you a Man? Have you a Soul? or Sense?
God buy you: take mine Office. O wretched Fool,
That lovest to make thine Honesty, a Vice!
O monstrous world! Take note, take note (O World)
To be direct and honest, is not safe.
I thank you for this profit, and from hence
I will love no Friend, sith Love breeds such offence.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Nay stay: thou shouldest be honest.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I should be wise; for Honesty is a Fool,
And looses that it works for.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: By the World,
I think my Wife be honest, and think she is not:
I think that thou art just, and think thou art not:
I will have some proof. My name that was as fresh
As Dians Visage, is now begrimed and black
As mine own face. If there be Cords, or Knives,
Poison, or Fire, or suffocating streams,
I will not endure it. Would I were satisfied.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I see you are eaten up with Passion:
I do repent me, that I put it to you.
You would be satisfied?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Would? Nay, and I will.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: And may: but how? How satisfied, my Lord?
Would you the super-vision grossly gape on?
Behold her topped?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Death, and damnation. O!

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: It were a tedious difficulty, I think,
To bring them to that Prospect: Damn them then,
If ever mortal eyes do see them bolster
More than their own. What then? How then?
What shall I say? Where is Satisfaction?
It is impossible you should see this,
Were they as prime as Goats, as hot as Monkeys,
As salt as Wolves in pride, and Fools as gross
As Ignorance, made drunk. But yet, I say,
If imputation, and strong circumstances,
Which lead directly to the door of Truth,
Will give you satisfaction, you might have it.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Give me a living reason she is disloyal.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I do not like the Office.
But sith I am entered in this cause so far
(Pricked to it by foolish Honesty, and Love)
I will go on. I lay with Cassio lately,
And being troubled with a raging tooth,
I could not sleep. There are a kind of men,
So loose of Soul, that in their sleeps will mutter
Their Affairs: one of this kind is Cassio:
In sleep I heard him say, sweet Desdemona,
Let us be wary, let us hide our Loves,
And then (Sir) would he gripe, and wring my hand:
Cry, o sweet Creature: then kiss me hard,
As if he plucked up kisses by the roots,
That grew upon my lips, laid his Leg over my Thigh,
And sigh, and kiss, and then cry cursed Fate,
That gave thee to the Moor.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O monstrous! monstrous!

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Nay, this was but his Dream.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: But this denoted a fore-gone conclusion,
It is a shrewd doubt, though it be but a Dream.

sp.speaker: Iago,
sp.l: And this may help to thicken other proofs,
That do demonstrate thinly.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I will tear her all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Nay yet be wise; yet we see nothing done,
She may be honest yet: Tell me but this,
Have you not sometimes seen a Handkerchief
Spotted with Strawberries, in your wife's hand?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I gave her such a one: it was my first gift.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I know not that: but such a Handkerchief
(I am sure it was your wife's) did I today
See Cassio wipe his Beard with.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: If it be that.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: If it be that, or any, it was hers.
It speaks against her with the other proofs.

sp.speaker: Othel.
sp.l: O that the Slave had forty thousand lives:
One is too poor, too weak for my revenge.
Now do I see it is true. Look here Iago,
All my fond love thus do I blow to Heaven. It is gone,
Arise black vengeance, from the hollow hell,
Yield up (O Love) thy Crown, and hearted Throne
To tyrannous Hate. Swell bosom with thy fraught,
For it is of Aspics tongues.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Yet be content.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O blood, blood, blood.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Patience I say: your mind may change.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Never Iago. Like to the Ponticke Sea,
Whose Icy Current, and compulsive course,
Never keeps retiring ebb, but keeps due on
To the Proponticke, and the Hellespont:
Even so my bloody thoughts, with violent pace
Shall never look back, never ebb to humble Love,
Till that a capable, and wide Revenge
Swallow them up. Now by yond Marble Heaven,
In the due reverence of a Sacred vow,
I here engage my words.

sp.speaker: >Iago.
sp.l: Do not rise yet:
Witness you ever-burning Lights above,
You Elements, that clip us round about,
Witness that here Iago doth give up
The execution of his wit, hands, heart,
To wronged Othello's Service. Let him command,
And to obey shall be in me remorse,
What bloody business ever.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I greet thy love,
Not with vain thanks, but with acceptance bounteous,
And will upon the instant put thee to it.
Within these three days let me hear thee say,
That Cassio's not alive.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: My Friend is dead:
It is done at your Request.
But let her live.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Damn her lewd Minx:
O damn her, damn her.
Come go with me apart, I will withdraw
To furnish me with some swift means of death
For the fair Devil.
Now art thou my Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I am your own for ever.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p:
Do you know Sirrah, where Lieutenant Cassio
lies?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I dare not say he lies any where.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Why man?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
He is a Soldier, and for me to say a Soldier lies,
it is stabbing.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Go to: where lodges he?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
To tell you where he lodges, is to tell you where
I lie.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Can anything be made of this?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise
a lodging, and say he lies here, or he lies there, were
to lie in mine own throat.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Can you enquire him out? and be edified by report?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I will Catechise the world for him, that is, make
Questions, and by them answer.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p:
Seek him, bid him come hither: tell him, I
have moved my Lord on his behalf, and hope all will
be well.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
To do this, is within the compass of man's Wit,
and therefore I will attempt the doing it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Where should I loose the Handkerchief, Aemilia?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: I know not Madam.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse
Full of Cruzadoes. And but my Noble Moor
Is true of mind, and made of no such baseness,
As jealous Creatures are, it were enough
To put him to ill-thinking.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Is he not jealous?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Who, he? I think the Sun where he was born,
Drew all such humours from him.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Look where he comes.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I will not leave him now, till Cassio be
Called to him. How is it with you, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Well my good Lady. O hardness to dissemble!
How do you, Desdemona?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Well, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Give me your hand.
This hand is moist, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: It hath felt no age, nor known no sorrow.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: This argues fruitfulness, and liberal heart:
Hot, hot, and moist. This hand of yours requires
A sequester from Liberty: Fasting, and Prayer,
Much Castigation, Exercise devout,
For here is a young, and sweating Devil here
That commonly rebels: It is a good hand,
A frank one.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: You may (indeed) say so:
For it was that hand that gave away my heart.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: A liberal hand. The hearts of old, gave hands:
But our new Heraldry is hands, not hearts.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I cannot speak of this:
Come, now your promise.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What promise, Chuck?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I have a salt and sorry Rheum offends me:
Lend me thy Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That which I gave you.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I have it not about me.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Not?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: No indeed, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That is a fault: That Handkerchief
Did an Aegyptian to my Mother give:
She was a Charmer, and could almost read
The thoughts of people. She told her, while she kept it,
It would make her Amiable, and subdue my Father
Entirely to her love: But if she lost it,
Or made a Gift of it, my Fathers eye
Should hold her loathed, and his Spirits should hunt
After new Fancies. She dying, gave it me,
And bid me (when my Fate would have me Wived)
To give it her. I did so; and take heed of it,
Make it a Darling, like your precious eye:
To lose it, or give it away, were such perdition,
As nothing else could match.

sp.speaker: Des,
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is true: There is Magic in the web of it:
A Sibyl that had numbered in the world
The Sun to course, two hundred compasses,
In her Prophetic fury sowed the Work:
The Worms were hallowed, that did breed the Silk,
And it was dyed in Mummy, which the Skilful
Conserved of Maidens hearts.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Indeed? Is it true?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Most veritable, therefore look to it well.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Then would to Heaven, that I had never seen it?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Ha? wherefore?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why do you speak so startingly, and rash?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Is it lost? Is it gon? Speak, is it out of the way?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Bless us.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Say you?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: It is not lost: but what and if it were?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I say it is not lost.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Fetch it, let me see it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why so I can: but I will not now:
This is a trick to put me from my suite,
Pray you let Cassio be received again.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Fetch me the Handkerchief,
My mind misgives.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Come, come: you will never meet a more sufficient man.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: The Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: A man that all his time
Hath founded his good Fortunes on your love;
Shared dangers with you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: The Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: In sooth, you are to blame.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Is not this man jealous?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I never saw this before.
Sure, there is some wonder in this Handkerchief,
I am most unhappy in the loss of it.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: It is not a year or two shows us a man:
They are all but Stomachs, and we all but Food,
They eat us hungrily, and when they are full
They belch us.
Look you, Cassio and my Husband.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: There is no other way: it is she must do it:
And lo the happiness: go, and importune her.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: How now (good Cassio) what is the news with
you?

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.l: Madam, my former suite. I do beseech you,
That by your virtuous means, I may again
Exist, and be a member of his love,
Whom I, with all the Office of my heart
Entirely honour, I would not be delayed.
If my offence, be of such mortal kind,
That nor my Service past, nor present Sorrows,
Nor purposed merit in futurity,
Can ransom me into his love again,
But to know so, must be my benefit:
So shall I clothe me in a forced content,
And shut myself up in some other course
To Fortunes Alms.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Alas (thrice-gentle Cassio)
My Advocation is not now in Tune;
My Lord, is not my Lord; nor should I know him,
Were he in Favour, as in Humour altered.
So help me every spirit sanctified,
As I have spoken for you all my best,
And stood within the blank of his displeasure
For my free speech. You must awhile be patient:
What I can do, I will: and more I will
Than for myself, I dare. Let that suffice you.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Is my Lord angry?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: He went hence but now:
And certainly in strange unquietness.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Can he be angry? I have seen the Cannon
When it hath blown his Ranks into the Air,
And like the Devil from his very Arm
Puffed his own Brother: And is he angry?
Something of moment then: I will go meet him,
There is matter in it indeed, if he be angry.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I prithee do so. Something sure of State,
Either from Venice, or some unhatched practise
Made demonstrable here in Cyprus, to him,
Hath puddled his clear Spirit: and in such cases,
Men's Natures wrangle with inferior things,
Though great ones are their object. It is even so.
For let our finger ache, and it endues
Our other healthful members, even to a sense
Of pain. Nay, we must think men are not Gods,
Nor of them look for such observance
As fits the Bridal. Beshrew me much, Aemilia,
I was (unhandsome Warrior, as I am)
Arraigning his unkindness with my soul:
But now I find, I had suborned the Witness,
And he is Indicted falsely.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Pray heaven it be
State matters, as you think, and no Conception,
Nor no Jealous Toy, concerning you.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Alas the day, I never gave him cause.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: But Jealous souls will not be answered so;
They are not ever jealous for the cause,
But jealous, for they are jealous. It is a Monster
Begot upon itself, borne on itself.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Heaven keep the Monster from Othello's mind.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Lady, Amen.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I will go seek him. Cassio, walk here about:
If I do find him fit, I will move your suite,
And seek to effect it to my uttermost.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Save you (Friend Cassio.)

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.l: What make you from home?
How is it with you, my most fair Bianca?
Indeed (sweet Love) I was coming to your house.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: And I was going to your Lodging, Cassio.
What? keep a week away? Seven days, and Nights?
Eight score eight hours? And Lovers absent hours
More tedious than the Dial, eight score times?
O weary reckoning.

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.l: Pardon me, Bianca:
I have this while with leaden thoughts been pressed,
But I shall in a more continuate time
Strike off this score of absence. Sweet Bianca
Take me this work out.

sp.speaker: Bianca.
sp.l: O Cassio, whence came this?
This is some Token from a newer Friend,
To the felt-Absence: now I feele a Cause:
Is it come to this? Well, well.

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.l: Go to, woman:
Throw your vild guesses in the Devils teeth,
From whence you have them. You are jealous now,
That this is from some Mistress, some remembrance;
No, in good troth Bianca.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Why, whose is it?

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.l: I know not neither:
I found it in my Chamber,
I like the work well; Ere it be demanded
(As like enough it will) I would have it copied:
Take it, and do it, and leave me for this time.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Leave you? Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.l: I do attend here on the General,
And think it no addition nor my wish
To have him see me womaned.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Why, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.l: Not that I love you not.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: But that you do not love me.
I pray you bring me on the way a little,
And say, if I shall see you soon at night?

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.l: It is but a little way that I can bring you,
For I attend here: But I will see you soon.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: It is very good: I must be circumstanced.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Will you think so?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Think so, Iago?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: What, to kiss in private?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: An unauthorised kiss?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Or to be naked with her Friend in bed,
An hour, or more, not meaning any harm?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Naked in bed (Iago) and not mean harm?
It is hypocrisy against the Devil:
They that mean virtuously, and yet do so,
The Devil their virtue tempts, and they tempt Heaven.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: If they do nothing, it is a Venial slip:
But if I give my wife a Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Why then it is hers (my Lord) and being hers,
She may (I think) bestow it on any man.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: She is Protectress of her honour too:
May she give that?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Her honour is an Essence that is not seen,
They have it very oft, that have it not.
But for the Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it:
Thou saidst (o, it comes over my memory,
As doth the Raven over the infectious house:
Boding to all) he had my Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Aye: what of that?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: That is not so good now.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What if I had said, I had seen him do you wrong?
Or heard him say (as Knaves be such abroad,
Who having by their own importunate suit,
Or voluntary dotage of some Mistress,
Convinced or supplied them, cannot choose
But they must blab.)

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Hath he said anything?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: He hath (my Lord) but be you well assured,
No more than he will un-swear.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What hath he said?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Why, that he did: I know not what he did.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: What? What?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Lie.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: With her?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: With her? On her: what you will.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.p:
Lie with her? lie on her? We say lie on her,
when they be-lie-her. Lie with her: that is fulsome:
Handkerchief: Confessions: Handkerchief. To confess,
and be hanged for his labour. First, to be hanged,
and then to confess: I tremble at it. Nature would not
invest herself in such shadowing passion, without some
Instruction. It is not words that shakes me thus, (pish)
Noses, Ears, and Lips: is it possible. Confess? Handkerchief?
O devil.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Work on,
My Medicine works. Thus credulous Fools are caught,
And many worthy, and chaste Dames even thus,
(All guiltless) meet reproach: what hoa? My Lord?
My Lord, I say: Othello.
How now Cassio?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: My Lord is fallen into an Epilepsy,
This is his second Fit: he had one yesterday.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Rub him about the Temples.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: The Lethargy must have his quiet course:
If not, he foams at mouth: and by and by
Breaks out to savage madness. Look, he stirs:
Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
He will recover straight: when he is gone,
I would on great occasion, speak with you.
How is it General? Have you not hurt your head?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Dost thou mock me?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I mock you not, by Heaven:
Would you would bear your Fortune like a Man.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: A Horned man's a Monster, and a Beast.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: There is many a Beast then in a populous City,
And many a civil Monster.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Did he confess it?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Good Sir, be a man:
Think every bearded fellow that is but yoked
May draw with you. There is Millions now alive,
That nightly lie in those unproperly beds,
Which they dare swear peculiar. Your case is better.
O, it is the spite of hell, the Fiends Arch-mock,
To lip a wanton in a secure Couch;
And to suppose her chaste. No, let me know,
And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O, thou art wise: it is certain.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Stand you a while apart,
Confine yourself but in a patient List,
Whilst you were here, overwhelmed with your grief
(A passion most resulting such a man)
Cassio came hither. I shifted him away,
And laid good scuses upon your Ecstasy,
Bad him anon return: and here speak with me,
The which he promised. Do but encaue yourself,
And mark the Fleers, the Gybes, and notable Scorns
That dwell in every Region of his face.
For I will make him tell the Tale anew;
Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when
He hath, and is again to cope your wife.
I say, but mark his gesture: marry Patience,
Or I shall say you are all in all in Spleen,
And nothing of a man.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Dost thou hear, Iago,
I will be found most cunning in my Patience:
But (dost thou hear) most bloody.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: That is not amiss,
But yet keep time in all: will you withdraw?
Now will I question Cassio of Bianca,
A Housewife that by selling her desires
Buys herself Bread, and Cloth. It is a Creature
That dotes on Cassio, (as it is the Strumpets plague
To be-guile many, and be be-guiled by one)
He, when he hears of her, cannot restrain
From the excess of Laughter. Here he comes.
As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad:
And his unbookish Jealousy must conserve
Poor Cassio's smiles, gestures, and light behaviours
Quite in the wrong. How do you Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: The worser, that you give me the addition,
Whose want even kills me.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure of it:
Now, if this Suit lay in Bianca's dower,
How quickly should you speed?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Alas poor Caitiff.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Look how he laughs already.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I never knew woman love man so.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Alas poor Rogue, I think indeed she loves me.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Now he denies it faintly: and laughs it out.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Do you hear Cassio?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Now he importunes him
To tell it over: go to, well said, well said.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: She gives it out, that you shall marry her.
Do you intend it?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Do ye triumph, Romaine? do you triumph?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
I marry. What? A customer; prithee bear
Some Charity to my wit, do not think it
So unwholesome. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: So, so, so, so: they laugh, that wins.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Why the cry goes, that you marry her.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Prithee say true.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: I am a very Villain else.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Have you scored me? Well.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
This is the Monkeys own giving out:
She is persuaded I will marry her
Out of her own love & flattery, not out of my promise.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Iago becomes me: now he begins the story.

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.p:
She was here even now: she haunts me in every
place. I was the other day talking on the Seabank with certain Venetians, and thither comes the
Bauble, and falls me thus about my neck.

sp.speaker: Oth
sp.p:
Crying o dear Cassio, as it were: his gesture imports
it.

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.p:
So hangs, and lolls, and weeps upon me:
So shakes, and pulls me. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
Now he tells how she plucked him to my Chamber:
o, I see that nose of yours, but not that dog, I
shall throw it to.

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.p: Well, I must leave her company.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Before me: look where she comes.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: It is such another Fitchew: marry a perfumed one?
What do you mean by this haunting of me?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p:
Let the devil, and his dam haunt you: what
did you mean by that same Handkerchief, you gave
me even now? I was a fine Fool to take it: I must take
out the work? A likely piece of work, that you should
find it in your Chamber, and know not who left it there.
This is some Minxes token, & I must take out the work?
There, give it your Hobbyhorse, wheresoever you had
it, I will take out no work of it.

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.p:
How now, my sweet Bianca?
How now? How now?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.p: By Heaven, that should be my Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p:
If you will come to supper tonight you may, if
you will not, come when you are next prepared for.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: After her: after her.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: I must, she will rail in the streets else.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Will you sup there?

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.p: Yes, I intend so.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
Well, I may chance to see you: for I would very
fain speak with you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Prithee come: will you?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Go to: say no more.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: How shall I murther him, Iago.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: O, Iago.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: And did you see the Handkerchief?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Was that mine?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
Yours by this hand: and to see how he prizes
the foolish woman your wife: she gave it him, and he
hath given it his whore.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
I would have him nine years a-killing:
A fine woman, a fair woman, a sweet woman?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Nay, you must forget that.

sp.speaker: Othello.
sp.p:
Aye, let her rot and perish, and be damned
tonight, for she shall not live. No, my heart is turned to
stone: I strike it, and it hurts my hand. O, the world
hath not a sweeter Creature: she might lie by an Emperors
side, and command him Tasks.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Nay, that is not your way.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.p:
Hang her, I do but say what she is: so delicate
with her Needle: an admirable Musician. O she will
sing the Savageness out of a Bear: of so high and plenteous
wit, and invention?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: She is the worse for all this.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.p:
O, a thousand, a thousand times:
And then of so gentle a condition?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Aye too gentle.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.p:
Nay that is certain:
But yet the pity of it, Iago: o Iago, the pity of it
Iago.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
If you are so fond over her iniquity: give her
patent to offend, for if it touch not you, it comes near
nobody.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: I will chop her into Messes: Cuckold me?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: O, it is foul in her.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: With mine Officer?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: That is fouler.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.p:
Get me some poison, Iago, this night. I will not
expostulate with her: lest her body and beauty unproved
my mind again: this night Iago.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
Do it not with poison, strangle her in her bed,
Even the bed she hath contaminated.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
Good, good:
The Justice of it pleases: very good.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker:
You shall hear more by midnight.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.p: Excellent good:
sp.l: What Trumpet is that same?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I warrant something from Venice,
It is Lodouico, this, comes from the Duke.
See, your wife's with him.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: Save you worthy General.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: With all my heart Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The Duke, and the Senators of Venice greet you.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: I kiss the Instrument of their pleasures.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: And what is the news, good cozen Lodouico?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I am very glad to see you Signior:
Welcome to Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I thank you: how does Lieutenant Cassio?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Lives Sir,

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Cozen, there is fallen between him, & my Lord,
An unkind breach: but you shall make all well.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Are you sure of that?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.p: This fail you not to do, as you will ---

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He did not call: he is busy in the paper,
Is there division betwixt my Lord, and Cassio?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: A most unhappy one: I would do much
To attone them, for the love I bear to Cassio.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Fire, and brimstone.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Are you wise?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: What is he angry?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: May be th Letter moved him.
For as I think, they do command him home,
Deputing Cassio in his Government.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Trust me, I am glad of it.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: I am glad to see you mad.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why, sweet Othello?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Devil.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I have not deserved this.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My Lord, this would not be believed in Venice,
Though I should swear I saw it. It is very much,
Make her amends: she weeps.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: O devil, devil:
If that the Earth could teem with woman's tears,
Each drop she falls, would prove a Crocodile:
Out of my sight.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I will not stay to offend you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Truly obedient Lady:
I do beseech your Lordship call her back.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: What would you with her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who I, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Aye, you did wish, that I would make her turn:
Sir, she can turn, and turn: and yet go on
And turn again. And she can weep, Sir, weep.
And she is obedient: as you say obedient.
Very obedient: proceed you in your tears.
Concerning this Sir, (o well-painted passion)
I am commanded home: get you away:
I will send for you anon. Sir I obey the Mandate,
And will return to Venice. Hence, avaunt:
Cassio shall have my Place. And Sir, tonight
I do entreat, that we may sup together.
You are welcome Sir to Cyprus.
Goats, and Monkeys.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is this the Noble Moor, whom our full Senate
Call all in all sufficient? Is this the Nature
Whom Passion could not shake? Whose solid virtue
The shot of Accident, nor dart of Chance
Could neither graze, nor pierce?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: He is much changed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Are his wits safe? Is he not light of Brain?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: He is that he is: I may not breath my censure.
What he might be: if what he might, he is not,
I would to heaven he were.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What? Strike his wife?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I'faith that was not so well: yet would I knew
That stroke would prove the worst.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is it his use?
Or did the Letters, work upon his blood,
And new create his fault?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Alas, alas:
It is not honesty in me to speak
What I have seen, and known. You shall observe him,
And his own courses will denote him so,
That I may save my speech: do but go after
And mark how he continues.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I am sorry that I am deceived in him.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: You have seen nothing then?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Nor ever heard: nor ever did suspect.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Yes, you have seen Cassio, and she together.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.l: But then I saw no harm: and then I heard,
Each syllable that breath made up between them.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: What? Did they never whisper?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Never my Lord.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Nor send you out of the way?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: To fetch her Fan, her Gloves, her Mask, nor no thing?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Never my Lord.

sp.speaker: Othe:
sp.l: That is strange.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: I durst (my Lord) to wager, she is honest:
Lay down my Soul at stake: If you think other,
Remove your thought. It doth abuse your bosom:
If any wretch have put this in your head,
Let Heaven requite it with the Serpents curse,
For if she be not honest, chaste, and true,
There is no man happy. The purest of their Wives
Is foul as Slander.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Bid her come hither: go.
She says enough: yet she is a simple Bawd
That cannot say as much. This is a subtle Whore:
A Closet Lock and Key of Villainous Secrets,
And yet she will kneel, and pray: I have seen her do it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: My Lord, what is your will?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Pray you Chuck come hither.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: What is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Let me see your eyes: look in my face.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: What horrible Fancy is this?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Some of your Function Mistress:
Leave Procreants alone, and shut the door:
Cough, or cry hem; if anybody come:
Your Mystery, your Mystery: May dispatch.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Upon my knee, what doth your speech import?
I understand a Fury in your words.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Why? What art thou?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Your wife my Lord: your true and loyal wife.

sp.speaker: Othello.
sp.l: Come swear it: damn thyself, lest
being like one of Heaven, the devils themselves should
fear to seize thee. Therefore be double damned: swear
thou art honest.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Heaven doth truly know it.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Heaven truly knows, that thou art false as hell.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: To whom my Lord?
With whom? How am I false?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Ah Desdemon, away, away, away.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Alas the heavy day: why do you weep?
Am I the motive of these tears my Lord?
If happily you my Father do suspect,
An Instrument of this your calling back,
Lay not your blame on me: if you have lost him,
I have lost him too.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Had it pleased Heaven,
To try me with Affliction, had they rained
All kind of Sores, and Shames on my bare-head:
Steeped me in poverty to the very lips.
Given to Captivity, me, and my utmost hopes,
I should have found in some place of my Soul
A drop of patience. But alas, to make me
The fixed Figure for the time of Scorn,
To point his slow, and moving finger at.
Yet could I bear that too, well, very well:
But there where I have garnered up my heart,
Where either I must live, or bear no life,
The Fountain from the which my currant runs,
Or else dries up: to be discarded thence,
Or keep it as a Cistern, for foul Toads
To knot and gender in. Turn thy complexion there:
Patience, thou young and Rose-lipped Cherubim,
I here look grim as hell.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I hope my Noble Lord esteems me honest.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: O Aye, as Summer Flies are in the Shambles,
That quicken even with blowing. O thou weed:
Whoart so lovely fair, and smellest so sweet,
That the Sense aches at thee,
Would thou hadst never been born.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Was this fair Paper? This most goodly Book
Made to write Whore upon? What committed,
Committed? O, thou public Commoner,
I should make very Forges of my cheeks,
That would to Cinders burn up Modesty,
Did I but speak thy deeds. What committed?
Heaven stops the Nose at it, and the Moon winks:
The bawdy wind that kisses all it meets,
Is hushed within the hollow Mine of Earth
And will not hear it. What committed?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: By Heaven you do me wrong.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Are not you a Strumpet?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: No, as I am a Christian.
If to preserve this vessel for my Lord,
From any other foul unlawful touch
Be not to be a Strumpet, I am none.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: What, not a Whore?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: No, as I shall be saved.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: O Heaven forgive us.

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.l: I cry you mercy then.
I took you for that cunning Whore of Venice,
That married with Othello. You Mistress,
That have the office opposite to Saint Peter,
And keeps the gate of hell. You, you: I you.
We have done our course: there is money for your pains:
I pray you turn the key, and keep our counsel.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Alas, what does this Gentleman conceive?
How do you Madam? how do you my good Lady?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Faith, half a sleep.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.l: Good Madam,
What is the matter with my Lord?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: With who?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Why, with my Lord, Madam?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Who is thy Lord?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: He that is yours, sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I have none: do not talk to me, Aemilia,
I cannot weep: nor answers have I none,
But what should go by water. Prithee tonight,
Lay on my bed my wedding sheets, remember,
And call thy husband hither.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Here is a change indeed.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: It is meet I should be used so: very meet.
How have I been behaved, that he might stick
The smallest opinion on my least misuse?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: What is your pleasure Madam?
How is it with you?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I cannot tell: those that do teach young Babes
Do it with gentle means, and easy tasks.
He might have chid me so: for in good faith
I am a Child to chiding.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: What is the matter Lady?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Alas (Iago) my Lord hath so bewhored her,
Thrown such despite, and heavy terms upon her
That true hearts cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Am I that name, Iago?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: What name (fair Lady?)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Such as she said my Lord did say I was.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: He called her whore: a Beggar in his drink:
Could not have laid such terms upon his Callet.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Why did he so?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I do not know: I am sure I am none such.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Do not weep, do not weep: alas the day.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Hath she forsook so many Noble Matches?
Her Father? And her Country? And her Friends?
To be called Whore? Would it not make one weep?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: It is my wretched Fortune.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Beshrew him for it:
How comes this Trick upon him?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Nay, Heaven doth know.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.l: I will be hanged, if some eternal Villain,
Some busy and insinuating Rogue,
Some cogging, cozening Slave, to get some Office,
Have not devised this Slander: I will be hanged else.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Fie, there is no such man: it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: If any such there be, Heaven pardon him.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: A halter pardon him:
And hell gnaw his bones.
Why should he call her Whore?
Who keeps her company?
What Place? What Time?
What Form? What likelihood?
The Moor is abused by some most villainous Knave,
Some base notorious Knave, some scurvy Fellow.
O Heavens, that such companions thou wouldst unfold,
And put in every honest hand a whip
To lash the Rascals naked through the world,
Even from the East to the west.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Speak within door.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: O fie upon them: some such Squire he was
That turned your wit, the seamy-side without,
And made you to suspect me with the Moor.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: You are a Fool: go to.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Alas Iago,
What shall I do to win my Lord again?
Good Friend, go to him: for by this light of Heaven,
I know not how I lost him. Here I kneel:
If ere my will did trespass against his Love,
Either in discourse of thought, or actual deed,
Or that mine Eyes, mine Ears, or any Sense
Delighted them: or any other Form.
Or that I do not yet, and ever did,
And ever will, (though he do shake me off
To beggarly divorcement) Love him dearly,
Comfort forswear me. Unkindness may do much,
And his unkindness may defeat my life,
But never taint my Love. I cannot say Whore,
It does abhor me now I speak the word,
To do the Act, that might the addition earn,
Not the worlds Mass of vanity could make me.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I pray you be content: it is but his humour:
The business of the State does him offence.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: If it were no other.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: It is but so, I warrant,
Hark how these Instruments summon to supper:
The Messengers of Venice stays the meat,
Go in, and weep not: all things shall be well.
sp.stage: Exeunt Desdemona and Aemilia. Enter Rodorigo.
sp.p: How now Rodorigo?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
I do not find
That thou dealest justly with me.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: What in the contrary?

sp.speaker: Rodori.
sp.p:
Every day thou dafts me with some devise
Iago, and rather, as it seems to me now, keepest from
me all convenience, then supply me with the least advantage
of hope: I will indeed no longer endure it. Nor
am I yet persuaded to put up in peace, what already I
have foolishly suffered.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Will you hear me Rodorigo?

sp.speaker: Rodori.
sp.p:
I have heard too much: and your words and
Performances are no kin together.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: You charge me most unjustly.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.p:
With nought but truth: I have wasted myself
out of my means. The Jewels you have had from
me to deliver Desdemona, would half have corrupted a
Votarist. You have told me she hath received them,
and returned me expectations and comforts of sudden
respect, and acquaintance, but I find none.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Well, go to: very well.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
Very well, go to: I cannot go to, (man) nor
it is not very well. Nay I think it is scurvy: and begin to
find myself fopped in it.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Rodor.
sp.p:
I tell you, it is not very well: I will make myself
known to Desdemona. If she will return me my
Jewels, I will give over my Suit, and repent my unlawful
solicitation. If not, assure yourself, I will seek
satisfaction of you.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: You have said now.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.p:
Aye: and said nothing but what I protest intendment
of doing.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
Why, now I see there is mettle in thee: and
even from this instant do build on thee a better opinion
than ever before: give me thy hand Rodorigo.
Thou hast taken against me a most just exception:
but yet I protest I have dealt most directly in thy
Affair.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: It hath not appeared.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
I grant indeed it hath not appeared: and
your suspicion is not without wit and judgment.
But Rodorigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed, which
I have greater reason to believe now than ever (I
mean purpose, Courage, and Valour) this night
show it. If thou the next night following enjoy not
Desdemona, take me from this world with Treachery,
and devise Engines for my life.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Well: what is it? Is it within, reason and compass?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
Sir, there is especial Commission come from
Venice to depute Cassio in Othello's place.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
Is that true? Why then Othello and Desdemona
return again to Venice.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
O no: he goes into Mauritania and taketh
away with him the fair Desdemona, unless his abode
be lingered here by some accident. Wherein
none can be so determinate, as the removing of
Cassio.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: How do you mean removing him?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
Why, by making him uncapable of Othello's
place: knocking out his brains.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: And that you would have me to do.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p:
Aye: if you dare do yourself a profit, and a
right. He sups tonight with a Harlotry: and thither
will I go to him. He knows not yet of his Honourable
Fortune, if you will watch his going thence (which
I will fashion to fall out between twelve and one)
you may take him at your pleasure. I will be near
to second your Attempt, and he shall fall between
us. Come, stand not amazed at it, but go along with
me: I will show you such a necessity in his death, that
you shall think yourself bound to put it on him. It
is now high supper time: and the night grows to waste.
About it.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I will hear further reason for this.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.p: And you shall be satisfied.

div2.head: Scena Tertia.
div2.stage: Enter Othello, Lodouico, Desdemona, Aemilia, and Atendants.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I do beseech you Sir, trouble yourself no further.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O pardon me: it will do me good to walk.

sp.speaker: Lodoui.
sp.l: Madam, good night: I humbly thank your
Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Your Honour is most welcome.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Will you walk Sir?
sp.p: O Desdemona.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.p:
Get you to bed on the instant, I will be returned
forthwith: dismiss your Attendant there: looked
be done.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: How goes it now? He looks gentler than he did.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: He says he will return incontinent,
And hath commanded me to go to bed,
And bid me to dismiss you.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: Dismiss me?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: It was his bidding: therefore good Aemilia,
Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu.
We must not now displease him.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.p: Aye, would you had never seen him.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: So would not I: my love doth so approve him,
That even his stubbornness, his checks, his frowns,
(Prithee un-pin me) have grace and favour.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: I have laid those Sheets you bad me on the bed.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: All is one: good Father, how foolish are our minds?
If I do die before, prithee shroud me
In one of these same Sheets.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.p: Come, come: you talk.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: My Mother had a Maid called Barbary,
She was in love: and he she loved proved mad,
And did forsake her. She had a Song of Willough,
An old thing it was: but it expressed her Fortune,
And she died singing it. That Song tonight,
Will not go from my mind: I have much to do,
But to go hang my head all at one side
And sing it like poor Barbary: prithee dispatch.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: Shall I go fetch your Nightgown?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: No, un-pin me here,
This Lodouico is a proper man.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.p: A very handsome man.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: He speaks well.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.p:
I know a Lady in Venice would have walked
barefoot to Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: The poor Soul sat singing, by a Sycamore tree.
Sing all a green Willough:
Her hand on her bosom her head on her knee,
Sing Willough, Willough, Willough.
The fresh Streams ran by her, and murmured her moans
Sing Willough, etc.
Her salt tears fell from her, and softened the stones,
Sing Willough, etc. (Lay by these)
Willough, Willough. (Prithee high thee: he will come anon)
Sing all a green Willough must be my Garland.
Let nobody blame him, his scorn I approve.
(Nay that is not next. Hark, who is it that knocks?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.p: It is the wind.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I called my Love false Love: but what said he then?
Sing Willough, etc.
If I court mo women, you will couch with mo men.
So get thee gone, good night: mine eyes do itch:
Doth that bode weeping?

sp.speaker: Aemil,
sp.p: It is neither here, nor there.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I have heard it said so. O these Men, these men!
Dost thou in conscience think (tell me Aemilia)
That there be women do abuse their husbands
In such gross kind?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.p: There be some such, no question.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.p: Why, would not you?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: No, by this Heavenly light.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.p:
Nor I neither, by this Heavenly light:
I might do it as well in the dark.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: The world's a huge thing:
It is a great price, for a small vice.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: In troth, I think thou wouldst not.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.p:
In troth I think I should, and undo it when
I had done. Marry, I would not do such a thing for a
joint Ring, nor for measures of Lawn, nor for Gowns,
Petticoats, nor Caps, nor any petty exhibition. But for
all the whole world: why, who would not make her husband a Cuckold,
to make him a Monarch? I should venture
Purgatory for it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong
For the whole world.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
Des.
sp.l: I do not think there is any such woman.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.p:
Yes, a dozen: and as many to the vantage, as
would store the world they played for.
sp.l: But I do think it is their Husbands faults
If Wives do fall: (Say, that they slack their duties,
And pour our Treasures into foreign laps;
Or else break out in peevish Jealousies,
Throwing restraint upon us: Or say they strike us,
Or scant our former having in despite)
Why we have galls: and though we have some Grace,
Yet have we some Revenge. Let Husbands know,
Their wives have sense like them: They see, and smell,
And have their Palates both for sweet, and sour,
As Husbands have. What is it that they do,
When they change us for others? Is it Sport?
I think it is: and doth Affection breed it?
I think it doth. Is it Frailty that thus errs?
It is so too. And have not we Affections?
Desires for Sport? and Frailty, as men have?
Then let them use us well: else let them know,
The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Good night, good night:
Heaven me such uses send,
Not to pick bad, from bad; but by bad, mend.

div2.head: Actus Quintus. Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Here, stand behind this Bark,
Straight will he come:
Wear thy good Rapier bare, and put it home:
Quick, quick, fear nothing; I will be at thy Elbow,
It makes us, or it mars us, think on that,
And fix most firm thy Resolution.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Be near at hand, I may miscarry in it.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Here, at thy hand: Be bold, & take thy stand.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I have no great devotion to the deed,
And yet he hath given me satisfying Reasons:
It is but a man gone. Forth my Sword: he dies.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I have rubbed this young Quat almost to the sense,
And he grows angry. Now, whether he kill Cassio,
Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other,
Every way makes my gain. Live Rodorigo,
He calls me to a restitution large
Of Gold, and Jewels, that I bobbed from him,
As Gifts to Desdemona.
It must not be: If Cassio do remain,
He hath a daily beauty in his life,
That makes me ugly: and besides, the Moor
May unfold me to him: there stand I in much peril:
No, he must die. But so, I heard him coming.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I know his gate, it is he: Villain thou diest.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: That thrust had been mine enemy indeed,
But that my Coat is better than thou knowest:
I will make proof of thine.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O, I am slain.

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.l: I am maimed for ever:
Help hoa: Murther, murther.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: The voice of Cassio, Iago keeps his word.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O Villain that I am.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is even so.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O help hoa: Light, a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is he: O brave Iago, honest, and just,
That hast such Noble sense of thy Friends wrong,
Thou teachest me. Minion, your dear lies dead,
And your unblessed Fate highest: Strumpet I come:
For of my heart, those Charms thine Eyes, are blotted.
Thy Bed lust-stained, shall with Lusts blood be spotted.

div2.stage: Exit Othello. Enter Lodouico and Gratiano.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: What hoa? no Watch? No passage?
Murther, Murther.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: It is some mischance, the voice is very direful.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O help.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: Hark.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O wretched Villain.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Two or three groan. It is heavy night;
These may be counterfeits: Let us think it unsafe
To come into the cry, without more help.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Nobody come: then shall I bleed to death.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Hark.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Here is one comes in his shirt, with Light, and
Weapons.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Who is there?
Whose noise is this that cries on murther?

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: We do not know.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Do not you hear a cry?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Here, here: for heaven sake help me.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: This is Othello's Ancient, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: The same indeed, a very valiant Fellow.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: What are you here, that cry so grievously?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Iago? O I am spoiled, undone by Villains:
Give me some help.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: O me, Lieutenant!
What Villains have done this?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I think that one of them is hereabout.
And cannot make away.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: O treacherous Villains:
What are you there? Come in, and give some help.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O help me there.

sp.speaker: Cassio.
sp.l: That is one of them.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: O murderous Slave! O Villain!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O damned Iago! O inhumane Dog!

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Kill men in the dark?
Where be these bloody Thieves?
How silent is this Town? Hoa, murther, murther.
What may you be? Are you of good, or evil?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: As you shall prove us, praise us.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Signior Lodouico?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He Sir.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I cry you mercy: here is Cassio hurt by Villains.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Cassio?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: How is it Brother?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: My Leg is cut in two.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Marry heaven forbid:
Light Gentlemen, I will bind it with my shirt.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: What is the matter hoa? Who is it that cried?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Who is it that cried?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: O my dear Cassio,
My sweet Cassio: O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: O notable Strumpet. Cassio, may you suspect
Who they should be, that have thus mangled you?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: I am sorry to find you thus;
I have been to seek you.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Lend me a Garter. So: --- O for a Chair
To bear him easily hence.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Alas he faints. O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Gentlemen all, I do suspect this Trash
To be a party in this Injury.
Patience awhile, good Cassio. Come, come;
Lend me a Light: know we this face, or no?
Alas my Friend, and my dear Countryman
Rodorigo? No: Yes sure: Yes, it is Rodorigo.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: What, of Venice?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Even he Sir: Did you know him?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Know him? I.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Signior Gratiano? I cry your gentle pardon:
These bloody accidents must excuse my Manners,
That so neglected you.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: I am glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: How do you Cassio? O, a Chair, a Chair.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Rodorigo?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: He, he, it is he:
O that is well said, the Chair.
Some good man bear him carefully from hence,
I will fetch the General's Surgeon. For you Mistress,
Save you your labour. He that lies slain here (Cassio)
Was my dear friend. What malice was between you?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: None in the world: nor do I know the man?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: What? look you pale? O bear him on the air.
Stay you good Gentlemen. Look you pale, Mistress?
Do you perceive the ghastness of her eye?
Nay, if you stare, we shall hear more anon.
Behold her well: I pray you look upon her:
Do you see Gentlemen? Nay, guiltiness will speak
Though tongues were out of use.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Alas, what is the matter?
What is the matter, Husband?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Cassio hath here been set on in the dark
By Rodorigo, and Fellows that are scaped:
He is almost slain, and Rodorigo quite dead.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Alas good Gentleman: alas good Cassio.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: This is the fruits of whoring. Prithee Aemilia,
Go know of Cassio where he supped tonight.
What, do you shake at that?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: He supped at my house, but I therefore shake not.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: O did he so? I charge you go with me.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: O fie upon thee Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: I am no Strumpet, but of life as honest,
As you that thus abuse me.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: As I? Fie upon thee.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Kind Gentlemen:
Let us go see poor Cassio dressed.
Come Mistress, you must tell us another Tale.
Aemilia, run you to the Citadel,
And tell my Lord and Lady, what hath happed:
Will you go on afore? This is the night
That either makes me, or foredoes me quite.

div2.head: Scoena Secunda.
div2.stage: Enter Othello, and Desdemona in her bed.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is the Cause, it is the Cause (my Soul)
Let me not name it to you, you chaste Stars,
It is the Cause. Yet I will not shed her blood,
Nor scar that whiter skin of hers, than Snow,
And smooth as Monumental Alabaster:
Yet she must die, else she will betray more men:
Put out the Light, and then put out the Light:
If I quench thee, thou flaming Minister,
I can again thy former light restore,
Should I repent me. But once put out thy Light,
Thou cunningest Pattern of excelling Nature,
I know not where is that PromethAean heat
That can thy Light re-Lume.
When I have plucked thy Rose,
I cannot give it vital growth again,
It needs must wither. I will smell thee on the Tree.
O Balmy breath, that dost almost persuade
Justice to break her Sword. One more, one more:
Be thus when thou art dead, and I will kill thee,
And love thee after. One more, and that is the last.
So sweet, was never so fatal. I must weep,
But they are cruel Tears: This sorrow's heavenly,
It strikes, where it doth love.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Who is there? Othello?

sp.speaker: Othel.
sp.l: I Desdemona.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Will you come to bed, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Have you prayed tonight, Desdemon?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: If you bethink yourself of any Crime
Unreconciled as yet to Heaven, and Grace,
Solicit for it straight.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Alack, my Lord,
What may you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Well, do it, and be brief, I will walk by:
I would not kill thy unprepared Spirit,
No, Heavens fore-fend) I would not kill thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Talk you of killing?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Aye, I do.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Then Heaven have mercy on me.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Amen, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: If you say, I hope you will not kill me.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Humh.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: And yet I fear you: for you are fatal then
When your eyes roll so.
Why I should fear, I know not,
Since guiltiness I know not: But yet I feele I fear.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Think on thy sins.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: They are Loves I bear to you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Aye, and for that thou diest.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: That death's unnatural, that kills for loving.
Alas, why gnaw you so your nether-lip?
Some bloody passion shakes your very Frame:
These are portents: but yet I hope, I hope,
They do not point on me.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Peace, and be still.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I will so: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Which I so loved, and gave thee, thou gavest to Cassio.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: No by my Life, and Soul: send for the man,
And ask him.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Sweet Soul, take heed, take heed of Perjury,
Thou art on thy death-bed.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Aye, but not yet to die.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Presently.
Therefore confess thee freely of thy sin:
For to deny each Article with Oath,
Cannot remove, nor choake the strong Conception
That I do groan withal. Thou art to die.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: O Heaven have mercy on me.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I say, Amen.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: And have you mercy too. I never did
Offend you in my life: never loved Cassio,
But with such general warranty of Heaven,
As I might love. I never gave him Token.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: By Heaven I saw my Handkerchief in his hand.
O perjured woman, thou dost stone my heart,
And makes me call, what I intend to do,
A Murther, which I thought a Sacrifice.
I saw the Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: He found it then:
I never gave it him: Send, for him hither:
Let him confess a truth.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: He hath confessed.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: What, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That he hath used thee.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: How? unlawfully?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: He will not say so.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: No: his mouth is stopped:
Honest Iago hath taken order for it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: O, my fear interprets. What is he dead?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Had all his hairs been lives, my great Revenge
Had stomach for them all.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Alas, he is betrayed, and I undone.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Out Strumpet: weepest thou for him to my face?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: O banish me, my Lord, but kill me not.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Down Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Kill me tomorrow, let me live tonight.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Nay, if you strive.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: But half an hour.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Being done, there is no pause.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: But while I say one prayer.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is too late.

sp.speaker: Aemil
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord? What hoa?
My Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What noise is this? Not dead? not yet quite dead?
I that am cruel, am yet merciful,
I would not have thee linger in thy pain?
So, so.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: within. What hoa? my Lord, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: O good my Lord, I would speak a word
with you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Yes: It is Aemilia: by and by. She is dead.
It is like she comes to speak of Cassio's death:
The noise was high. Hah, no more moving?
Still as the Grave. Shall she come in? Wert good?
I think she stirs again. No, what is best to do?
If she come in, she will sure speak to my wife:
My wife, my wife: what wife? I have no wife.
O insupportable! O heavy hour!
Methinks, it should be now a huge Eclipse
Of Sun, and Moon; and that the affrighted Globe
Did yawn at Alteration.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: I do beseech you
That I may speak with you. O good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I had forgot thee: o come in Aemilia.
Soft, by and by, let me the Curtains draw.
Where art thou? What is the matter with thee now?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: O my good Lord, yonder is foul Murthers
done.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What? now?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: But now, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is the very error of the Moon,
She comes more nearer Earth than she was wont,
And makes men mad.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Cassio, my Lord, hath killed
A young Venetian, called Rodorigo.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Rodorigo killed? and Cassio killed?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: No, Cassio is not killed.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Not Cassio killed? Then Murder is out of tune,
And sweet Revenge grows harsh.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: O falsely, falsely murdered.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Alas! what cry is that?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That? What?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Out, and alas, that was my Ladies voice.
Help, help hoa, help. O Lady speak again,
Sweet Desdemona, o sweet Mistress, speak.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: A guiltless death, I die.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: O who hath done this deed?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Nobody: I myself, farewell:
Commend me to my kind Lord: o farewell.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Why, how should she be murdered?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Alas: who knows?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: You hear her say herself, it was not I.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: She said so: I must needs report the truth.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: She is like a Liar gone to burning hell,
It was I that killed her.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: O the more Angel she, and you the blacker
Devil.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: She turned to folly: and she was a whore.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: She was false as water.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Thou art rash as fire, to say
That she was false. O she was heavenly true.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Cassio did top her: Ask thy husband else.
O, I were damned beneath all depth in hell:
But that I did proceed upon just grounds
To this extremity. Thy Husband knew it all.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: My Husband?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Thy Husband.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: That she was false to Wedlock?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Aye, with Cassio: had she been true,
If Heaven would make me such another world,
Of one entire and perfect Chrysolite,
I would not have sold her for it.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: My Husband?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I, it was he that told me of her first,
An honest man he is, and hates the slime
That sticks on filthy deeds.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: My Husband?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What needs this iterance, Woman?
I say, thy Husband.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: O Mistress,
Villainy hath made mocks with love:
My Husband say she was false?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: He, Woman;
I say thy Husband: Dost understand the word?
My Friend, thy Husband; honest, honest Iago.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: If he say so, may his pernicious Soul
Rot half a grain a day: he lies to the heart,
She was too fond of her most filthy Bargain.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Do thy worst:
This deed of thine is no more worthy Heaven,
Than thou was it worthy her.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Peace, you were best.

sp.speaker: Aemil
sp.l: Thou hast not half that power to do me harm,
As I have to be hurt. O Gull, o dolt,
As ignorant as dirt: thou hast done a deed
(I care not for thy Sword) I will make thee known,
Though I lost twenty lives. Help, help, hoa, help:
The Moor hath killed my Mistress. Murther, murther.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What is the matter? How now General?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: O, are you come, Iago: you have done well,
That men must lay their Murthers on your neck.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: Disprove this Villain, if thou be-est a man:
He says, thou toldest him that his wife was false:
I know thou didst not: thou art not such a Villain.
Speak, for my heart is full.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I told him what I thought,
And told no more
Than what he found himself was apt, and true.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: But did you ever tell him,
She was false?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Aemil.
sp.l: You told a Lie an odious damned Lie:
Upon my Soul, a Lie; a wicked Lie.
She false with Cassio?
Did you say with Cassio?

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: With Cassio, Mistress?
Go to, charm your tongue.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I will not charm my Tongue;
I am bound to speak,
My Mistress here lies murthered in her bed.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O Heavens, forfend.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: And your reports have set the Murder on.

sp.speaker: Othello.
sp.l: Nay stare not Masters,
It is true indeed.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: It is a strange Truth.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O monstrous Act.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Villainy, villainy, villainy:
I think upon it, I think: I smell it: O Villainy:
I thought so then: I will kill myself for grief.
O villainy! villainy!

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: What, are you mad?
I charge you get you home.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen, let me have leave to speak:
It is proper I obey him; but not now:
Perchance Iago, I will never go home.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Nay; lay thee down, and roar:
For thou hast killed the sweetest innocent,
That ere did lift up eye.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O she was foul!
I scarce did know you Uncle, there lies your Niece,
Whose breath (indeed) these hands have newly stopped:
I know this act shows horrible and grim.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Poor Desdemon:
I am glad thy Father is dead,
Thy Match was mortal to him: and pure grief
Shore his old thread in twain. Did he live now,
This sight would make him do a desperate turn:
Yea, curse his better Angel from his side,
And fall to Reprobance.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is pitiful: but yet Iago knows
That she with Cassio, hath the Act of shame
A thousand times committed. Cassio confessed it,
And she did gratify his amorous works
With that Recognisance and pledge of Love
Which I first gave her: I saw it in his hand:
It was a Handkerchief, an Antique Token
My Father gave my Mother.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: O Heaven! o
heavenly Powers!

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Come, hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: It will out, it will out. I peace?
No, I will speak as liberal as the North;
Let Heaven, and Men, and Devils, let them all,
All, all, cry shame against me, yet I will speak.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Be wise, and get you home.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Fie, your Sword upon a Woman.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: O thou dull Moor,
That Handkerchief thou speakest of
I found by Fortune, and did give my Husband:
For often, with a solemn earnestness,
(More than indeed belonged to such a Trifle)
He begged of me, to steal it.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Villainous Whore.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: She give it Cassio? No, alas I found it,
And I did give it my Husband.

sp.speaker: Iago.
sp.l: Filth, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: By Heaven I do not, I do not Gentlemen:
O murderous Coxcomb, what should such a Fool
Do with so good a wife?

sp.speaker: Oth.
